children.value: Gap Filling
This notebook will show some algorithms to fill gaps of vector data and raster data. The notebook is structured as follows:
Gap Filling of a vector dataset in spatial domain
Gap filling of a raster dataset in temporal and spatial domain

from esa_climate_toolbox.core import get_op
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
import numpy as np
import scipy.interpolate as interp
import xarray as xr
from xcube.core.store import new_data_store
To get access to the data, we will initiate the ESA CCI Zarr store in the following cell.
store = new_data_store('esa-cci-zarr')
1. Gap Filling of a Vector Dataset in the Spatial Domain

children.label: 1. Gap Filling of a Vector Dataset in the Spatial Domain

children.value: In this example, we will work with trend data of the Greenland ice sheet, which is provided as a set of spatial points over a given time range. We will apply several interpolation algorithms to fill the gaps between these points, ultimately converting the data into a raster format.
First we will open the data as usual.

ds = store.open_data("ESACCI-ICESHEETS_Greenland_GMB-2003-2016-v1.1.zarr")
ds

text/plain.content:
<xarray.Dataset> Size: 43kB
Dimensions:     (meas_ind: 901, time: 10)
Dimensions without coordinates: meas_ind, time
Data variables:
    GMB_trend   (meas_ind, time) float32 36kB dask.array<chunksize=(901, 10), meta=np.ndarray>
    end_time    (time) datetime64[ns] 80B dask.array<chunksize=(10,), meta=np.ndarray>
    latitude    (meas_ind) float32 4kB dask.array<chunksize=(901,), meta=np.ndarray>
    longitude   (meas_ind) float32 4kB dask.array<chunksize=(901,), meta=np.ndarray>
    start_time  (time) datetime64[ns] 80B dask.array<chunksize=(10,), meta=np.ndarray>
    t           (time) datetime64[ns] 80B dask.array<chunksize=(10,), meta=np.ndarray>
Attributes: (12/20)
    Institution:          DTU Space - Div. of Geodynamics
    Latitude_max:         83.23728
    Latitude_min:         60.73857
    Longitude_max:        -14.706720000000018
    Longitude_min:        -71.83566000000002
    Method:               GRACE GMB trend following Barletta et al. 2012
    ...                   ...
    grid_projection:      Geographical coordinates relative to WGS84
    netCDF_version:       NETCDF3_CLASSIC
    product_version:      1.2
    time_coverage_end:    2016-01-31
    time_coverage_start:  2003-01-01
    time_resolution:      5Y

children.value: We define the final coordiates of the resired target raster and extract one time slice from the data set.

lon = np.arange(-73., -12., 0.02)
lat = np.arange(83., 59., -0.02)
grid_lon, grid_lat = np.meshgrid(lon, lat)
GMB_trend_slice = ds.GMB_trend.isel(time=0)
Now we can perform a 2D linear interpolation using
scipy.interpolate.griddata

gridded_data = interp.griddata(
    (ds.longitude, ds.latitude),
    GMB_trend_slice, 
    (grid_lon, grid_lat), 
    method='linear'
)
ds_linear = xr.Dataset(
    {'GMB_trend_slice': (['lat', 'lon'], gridded_data)},
    coords={'lon': lon, 'lat': lat}
)
ds_linear

children.value: The same approach can be applied using
"cubic"
as the interpolation method.

gridded_data = interp.griddata(
    (ds.longitude, ds.latitude),
    GMB_trend_slice, 
    (grid_lon, grid_lat), 
    method="cubic"
)
ds_cubic = xr.Dataset(
    {'GMB_trend_slice': (['lat', 'lon'], gridded_data)},
    coords={'lon': lon, 'lat': lat}
)
ds_cubic

children.value: Now, we can plot the results: the left plot shows the original points from the ESA CCI ice sheet trend dataset, the center plot displays the linear interpolation, and the right plot presents the cubic interpolation.

fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 3, figsize=(20, 6))
scatter = ax[0].scatter(
    ds.longitude, ds.latitude, c=GMB_trend_slice, cmap='seismic', vmin=-500, vmax=500, s=30
)
ax[0].set_title('Scatter Plot of Values on 2D Grid')
ax[0].set_ylabel('lat')
ax[0].set_xlabel('lon')
fig.colorbar(scatter, ax=ax[0], orientation='vertical')
ds_linear.GMB_trend_slice.plot(ax=ax[1], vmin=-500, vmax=500, cmap='seismic')
ax[1].set_title('Linear interpolation')
ds_cubic.GMB_trend_slice.plot(ax=ax[2], vmin=-500, vmax=500, cmap='seismic')
ax[2].set_title('Cubic interpolation')
2. Gap filling of a raster dataset

children.label: 2. Gap filling of a raster dataset

children.value: In this example, we will work with the soil moisture dataset, which is a 3d rastered dataset with gaps in it. We will show an example how to fill the gaps along the time axis for a time series and how to fill the pags in the 2d spatial domain.
First we will open the data as usual.

ds = store.open_data('ESACCI-SOILMOISTURE-L3S-SSMV-COMBINED-1978-2021-fv07.1.zarr')
ds

text/plain.content:
<xarray.Dataset> Size: 654GB
Dimensions:         (time: 15767, lat: 720, lon: 1440)
Coordinates:
  * lat             (lat) float64 6kB 89.88 89.62 89.38 ... -89.38 -89.62 -89.88
  * lon             (lon) float64 12kB -179.9 -179.6 -179.4 ... 179.6 179.9
  * time            (time) datetime64[ns] 126kB 1978-11-01 ... 2021-12-31

children.value: Gap filling along the time axis

children.label: Gap filling along the time axis

children.value: For this, we create a small function that removes all NaN values and then performs interpolation to the original time axis using
xarray.Dataset.interp()
We will apply this gap-filling method to one year of the dataset as an example. To do this, we subset the dataset and select the year 2000.

ds_ts = ds.sel(lat=20, lon=20, method="nearest")
ds_ts = ds_ts.sel(time=slice('2000-01-01 00:00:00', '2001-01-01 00:00:00'))
ds_ts

children.value: Next, we apply the gap-filling method to the selected sample.

ds_ts_gap_fill = fill_temporal_gaps(ds_ts)
ds_ts_gap_fill

children.value: We then plot the original and gap-filled soil moisture dataset, zooming in on a two-month period to better highlight the gap-filling effect.

time_slice = slice('2000-06-01 00:00:00', '2000-08-01 00:00:00')
ds_ts.sm.sel(time=time_slice).plot(label="Original")
ds_ts_gap_fill.sm.sel(time=time_slice).plot(label="Gap filling", linestyle="dashed")
plt.legend()
Gap Filling in the Spatial Domain

children.label: Gap Filling in the Spatial Domain

children.value: In this example, we utilize the low-pass gap-filling algorithm from
gridtools
(DOI
). This method effectively applies a 2D low-pass filter to the data. As a demonstration, we select a single time slice and apply gap filling in the spatial domain using the aforementioned algorithm.

sm_slice = ds.sm.sel(time='2000-07-01 12:00:00', method='nearest')
sm_slice

children.value: Next, we apply the toolbox’s gap-filling operation, which is highly efficient as it leverages Numba for parallel computation.
gapfill_op = get_op('gapfill')

ds_filled = gapfill_op(ds_sub)
ds_filled.sm

children.value: Finally, we plot the results for North Africa as an example to illustrate the gap-filling process.

fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(20, 5))
extent = dict(lat=slice(30, 10), lon=slice(-15, 35))
ds_sub.sm.sel(**extent).plot(ax=ax[0])
ds_filled.sm.sel(**extent).plot(ax=ax[1])
